quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: Sometimes you don't need to experiment. Sometimes if the business, let's say activation, right, activation rates go up 6% versus 7%, that precision actually doesn't help all that much beyond being able to say in your performance review, 'Hey, I increased activation by 7%.'

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: Generally my advice is to experiment when you need to and to primarily see it as a risk mitigation tactic when you're making dramatic changes and to let the product development process do more work.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: The only way to escape the trap of experimenting everything is to have a very intentional culture about doing right by customers and doing the right thing for the business. A growth team or a growth org exists in service of improving the business and delivering results for the business.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: An activation rate that falls in a lower percentage range, maybe for most companies five to 15%, is better than one that falls in a higher percentage range because it means that there's likely much higher correlation with long-term retention and you're really working hard to get most of your users to reach a state that they're not reaching today.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: Celebrate any clear statistical significant improvement in activation rate. It's a big victory. I think it speaks to the importance of really understanding what a user needs to be onboarded well, which is not the same as what your business wants the user to be onboarded to.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: We really worked hard to prioritize what the user actually needed and to consider what was necessary education versus what could be ongoing education and building it up.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: Bucketing customers by their learning style and their building style was more effective than more classic segmentation, like do you work in marketing, do you work in product management, do you work in operations.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: I find sometimes teams working on onboarding will map onboarding to that pricing or packaging. It can be tempting for an onboarding team to try to push automations to people when they're getting started because of course, we'd prefer if customers use premium features because then they might be more likely to become premium customers, but that is not in the best interest of educating a user on how to get started.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: A common trap is that employees of a company build onboarding for customers, but they build what they think customers want rather than what customers actually want, and that manifests in an onboarding experience that's not very helpful. One pattern I typically see is naming features rather than explaining how the feature is relevant to the user.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: User growth is important and if you're in a long game where you're trying to grow a business for a decade or more, ideally you're trying to get millions of people onto your product and you can always have that monetization conversation later, but you only get a couple moments where you can say, 'Hey, pull out your credit card,' with a customer before you lose trust or lose patience.

quotes.speaker: Lauryn Isford
quotes.text: Sometimes we overfocus on picking the perfect north star metric and by the time you feel like you've found the perfect one, it's actually time to move on to something different and work on a different opportunity.

takeaways: Not everything needs to be an A/B test -- experimentation is primarily a risk mitigation tactic, and over-reliance on it slows teams down and biases toward short-term thinking.
A lower activation rate (5-15%) that strongly correlates with long-term retention is far more valuable than a higher one that loosely predicts outcomes.
Segment onboarding by learning style and building style rather than job title or department -- how users learn matters more than what they do.
Onboarding should teach users what they need, not push premium features -- mapping onboarding to your pricing package prioritizes the company's interests over the customer's journey.
Growth teams should be agile about their north star metric -- spending too long finding the perfect one wastes time that could be spent chasing the next big opportunity.

contrarian_candidates.why: Most growth leaders evangelize experimentation as essential to everything; Lauryn argues teams over-experiment and it's actually an expensive cost that slows them down.
Counterintuitive that you should prefer a lower activation rate -- most teams celebrate high activation percentages without questioning correlation strength.
Challenges the conventional wisdom that teams need a stable, unchanging north star metric -- argues you should be willing to change it as opportunities shift.
